intro: Gypsophila mongolica, commonly known as the Mongolian laceflower, is a perennial herb native to the steppes of Mongolia and adjacent regions. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae and is characterized by its delicate, fern-like foliage and clusters of small, white or pink flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in well-drained, sandy or loamy soils. It is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, showcasing drought tolerance and a deep root system. Gypsophila mongolica is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
